Keep no more cows than You can keep
well-One COW we'll ted will produce as
much milk as two indifferently treated, anu
more butter; and if the COW be wlntereo
badly, She will rarely recover during the
succeeding summer, SO, as to become pro,
fitable to the feeder.--Cows should by an
means, be housed in extreme weather, ana
particularly those which give miik' or a
failure in the quantity Of milk will be eN-
perienced. Wherefore instead OF keeping
twenty cows poorly fed and but halt OF them
stabbed, sell ten, and give the remaining ten
feed to the amount equal to what the twenty
originally had; procure constant sta5ling tor
them, and YOU will receive quite as mucn
milk and butter in return, as was derived
from the former mode OF treating twenty,
Sweet potatoes, carrots, pumpkins, ana
ground oats, are unquestionably among the


best articles of food for mich cattle; they
occasion the milk to assume hne flavor ana


colour as well as an Increase OF quantity.

It seems not generally apprehended OF II
apprehended, not acted upon, that husoaha-
~ or farming, like the mechanic arts, IN or
der to be most profitable to those engaged
in il. lshould be divided and subdivided INTO
its distinct and separate branches. Inc
blacksmith to his anvil, the cobler to his last,
the carpenter to his adze, and SO on OF the
other branches of mechanical labors; no one
thinks of CARRYING on all these at one and the
same time.-But the farmer appears not TO
appreciate the advantage OF conflning MS Ia
hors to any one branch OF husbandry, the
converting of effort and attention to one
Doint; and yet this is, in fact, as important
in husbandry as in mechanism. AND u Is
owing TO this mistaken policy, no doubt IN
great measure, that the art of husbandry
has advanced SO slowly, and the profit SO
small in comparison to the labor. A mo-
ment's reflection will show this natural re-
suit. By having tNe attention divided a
mong all the various branches. no one be-
comes particularly skilled in either, and
hence no branch becomes particularly pro
ftable. By keeping few cows for dairyln
a few swine, few sheep, fattenlng is"
beeves raising little grain, little max, &c.
the attention and resources OF a common tar
mer are SO divided, that the whole yield but
discouraging result; whereas, by conflnlng
his attention to either of these, or taking on
ly such as bear the nearest affinity and as.
sist one or the other he may hope to be-
come an adept in that particular branch,
and realize a corresponding profit. And IN
selecting the particular branch he will pur-
sue. the husbandman should not rashly a.
dopt that which chance speculation may
at the moment cry up as the most protita-
Bile; but should, in the first place, consider
for what his farm is more particularly a.
dapted, and what his resources will enable
him to have most perfectly at command; an1
then steadily and perseveringly pursue ~ I


AS the cobler to his last, so let the ! his [
man stick to his cows. the grazies. thro,


beeves, the wool grower to his Rtion. and


all the uha and dozYns Of spest either in
there is little apprehension complain that
the end will have cause abor, or is not
he gets no profits in hsperity
sharer in the general

Has opened his ACADEMY, at his residence, in
French street, two doors below Third street,
where will be taught the different branches of
practical Mathematics; the method of taking and
working Lunar Dissertations with the uses and
adjustment of all the instruments used in the
branches taught.


Should sufficient encouragement be given to
afford lt,a small photographic and Printing Press
will be attached to the Institution, by which the
pupils may be exercised III composition; Perspec-
tive and other drawings, things, essential to the
practical Scholar.


Pupils from distance will be accommodated
with Boarding at Two Dollars per week.

Would you view man that's slow,
Come and sec our fontmam Joe:--
Mu j unlike the bounding doe,
Or the arrow from the bow,
Is the pace Of foetman joe
Crabs, that hobble to and fro,
In their motions copy Joe;
Snails, contcmptuous as they go,
Look behind and sneer at doc;
An acre any man might NOV,
While across it crawleth lazy joe
Trip on light fantastic toe,
Who loves tripping may for Joe
Measured steps and solemn voc,
Better suit with steady joe
Danube, Severn, Trent and Po,
Backward TO their source shall flow,
Ere despatch be made by Joe;
Letters to the Penny Pc,


Send not by our footman Joe;
Would you Jobs full patience know,
Ring the bell and wait for joe
Whether it be King or no.
IT'S all the same to lazy Joe.
Is your cash and credit low
Let your debts be paid by Joe
Legal process none can know,
If your lawyer moves like Joe.
Death, at length, our common foe,
AIuct t,,t, ma tha heels Df I0a
And stone shall tell ssbelow
Scarcely changed still slcepeth Joe
Loud shall the final trumpet blow,
And the last conner shall be Joe.

Two miies ufa good Limestone quarry. hers is

Barley delights in sandy loan. Itror
erallv succeeds wheat, the land beingii ~
en- IN as soon after Christmast as r ,nro,s. H
NIT the plough lts ploughed ar, ;a, i !. !.
ed in March. In April the opfaf,ara..rtIe
gain repeated; the outstanding harrow ,rr and
taking care to render with y.n IND rs lev
roller, the entire surface stha rronnd i on

" ploughed once. and i ;s hroken bv three
but more frequents standmu they NAV not
ploughings, notwweek TO perform them in.
have more thasht. appears an injudicious
This, at hrsn,lonab bnes m being 50 qnick up-
pract'ee, her, neither the root weeds have
on eacRither, nor the seed weeds to vesct
tlmeBut this being frequent practice Of
aye of the best farmers, we may be assur-
ID that two ploughings and harrowngs are
lot wantonv thrown away.-lhe Norfolk
srmers are in general masters OF the art Of
barley. They seem fully aware
if the tenderness of this plant ~ is infant
state, and of its roofing being un Bile TO
make the proper progress IN a compact y
proper soil; they therefore strive by every
means in their power, to render the SOL as
fine as ashes, and fit forthc reception Of the
seed. The proper TING for sowing the seed
is from the middle OF April to the midele Of
MAY; but the time depends in some measure
upon the season; the true period sJnst be-
fore the oak iut& on Mat &ailo72 ahflear-
Qnce, which il does At the time the buds are
breaking, previous to the expansion OF the
leaves. Three bushels are usually allowed
to an acre, and sown broadcast; il is then
ploughed under with shallow furrow, an
admirable practice in soils light enough to
produce good barley, provided the seed is
not buried too deep. If tire season howev-
er is wet, and the soil cold and heavy, the
seed should be cast upon the surface, aud
then narrowed and rolled. as is the practice
in other districts.

come proyerbial, that "where


1t has. hard has stood, a young one will
and olde" This has been SO frequently
not Hed, that many of our good agricul-
Rests have subscribed to the opinion,
ithout taking the trouble to examine into
It, and have accordingly neglected very
important source of profit and convenience.
1t is fact much to be regretted that the
cultivation of fruit trees in this country was
much more attended to half a century since,
than at the present time--consequently
with our increased population, fruit has be
come scarce, and belief almost positively
exists, that fruit trees will not thrive OH old
land: This question needs serious consider
alton, that eur yeomanry may no longer
take hypothesis for fact, when but one ex
pertinent would dispel the Illusion.


We, however, admit the fact, that trees
planted on new land thrive uncommonly
we'll, and many of them grow to great
size, while those planted on land that has
been much cultivated and worn have been
tardy in their growth, and as yet are but
awarfs in comparison with the former Now
we will endeavor to explain the reason of
this admission which we trust will at the
same time throw some light on the art of
cultiyating fruit trees


/. Trees, planted fifty or one hundred
years since, were generally set on new land
highly enriched by the decayed vegetable
productions, which have been accommodating
perhaps from time immemorial. The rich
ness OF the soil would, without doubt, enable
the trees to grow rapidly, and very abund-
antly explain the reason of their monstrous
growth.


Q. An orchard set on the ruins of an old
one, has not this vegetable manure to lend
the aid that its predecessor had; consequent
ly, it is slow In its growth; small and unpro-
ductive when grown, becomes mossy, dwin-
dies and dies or is neglected as unworthy
the husbandman's attention; and the cater
pillar destroys what the axe has spared
Our climate and soil are every way calcu-
lated for the production OF fruit III its per-
fection and abundance, when only assisted
by the fostering hand OF art-and it is unrea-
sonable to anticipate harvest without pre-
vious cultivation, the early days of our
country the earth needed only the seed to be
gown to produce a rich harvest for its DO.
som was enriched and softrncd by natural
manure. The case is now different--it has
been skinned by grandfather, father and son
twice or thrice repeated until its face is sad
ly wasted.-Who is there among US, thai
would suppose tree would grow when un.
assisted by art, Or land thus impoverished
The farmer who thinks Of raising a gooe
crop of corn knows well the necessity O
sottening, manuring, and frequently stirrin,
the earth-on this depends his success Sup
pose he should say, with regard to his coin
as he does in fact OF his trees--my grea
grand father planted without hoeing or ma
nuring, and was sure of the increase, and
will do lkewise-would he not be STYLED
madman or fool? Let the husbandman be
stow the same care on am orchard, that h
does on field of corn, and he will be bles
with the same abundant harvest.


To him who doubts the possibility
making good orchard on old land thes
few simple rules are enjoned, and we dout
not, upon experiment, his happy convel
sion to truth that will increase his wealtl


1. Be sure that the roots of the trees /
below the soil. If the soil is shallow, bring
from another place, and throw it round th
tree, in sufficient circumference for the roo
TO grow in.


II. Prune the superhuous limbs an
branches and keep the bark smooth an
clean from moss.


Ill. Suffer no grass to grow within te
feet of the tree, and twice in the wear, sprin
and fall, loosen the earth in circumference,
and mix into it full wheelbarrow load
Iich manure.


The author is happy to state that fe
years experiment upon this plan on tn
ground Of an old orchard, has convinced hi
ehAt the principle oDpogcd to this rule

Gooseberrics require dead and rich loam
the ground must be well maliured and kept
free from weeds; and be careful to plant
none but those that are of good kind. lie
best mode of propagating them, is by cut
tngs or layers. Earlv in the spring, spade
carefully around the roots, turn overthe soil,
and pull out all grass that may grow near
them. Prune them by cutting out every
worn out, decaved, or irregular branch--et
none be permitted to grow across each 9th
er; but let all be pruned 10 some regular or
der--cut out all the super-abundant, lateral
shoots of the last summer, close to the
ground, or old wood, otly retaining Eere ard
there good one, to supply the place Of cas-
ual worn out bearers. Never permit the
extremities Of the branches to stand nearer
than six or eight inches 10 each other. The
best form for we'll trained gooseberry or
currant bush, is that of vine glass.


Gooae5erry It'ine is made il the same
manner as currant wine, except that one
third less sugar is quired. lnpicking the
berries take none that have fallen upon til.
ground, or that have been shaded and grown
sour.

the W1LMINGroNIAN. No. 81, Market-St..
on moderate terms Orders will meet with
prompt attention.

To keep potatoes any length Of time, The
most effectual way is to place them ii tlin
layers on platform suspended in N ile
cellar. There the temperature being Al
ways that of active vegetation they viii nor
sprout, while not being many deg IS below
the freezing point tubers will not be frost
bit Another mode is TO scoop out the eyes
by very small scoup, and keep the roots
buried in earth A third mode is to destroy
the vital principle by kiln drying steamng,
or scalding.

full articles.headline: COWS.
full articles.article:
Keep no more cows than You can keep
well-One COW we'll ted will produce as
much milk as two indifferently treated, anu
more butter; and if the COW be wlntereo
badly, She will rarely recover during the
succeeding summer, SO, as to become pro,
fitable to the feeder.--Cows should by an
means, be housed in extreme weather, ana
particularly those which give miik' or a
failure in the quantity Of milk will be eN-
perienced. Wherefore instead OF keeping
twenty cows poorly fed and but halt OF them
stabbed, sell ten, and give the remaining ten
feed to the amount equal to what the twenty
originally had; procure constant sta5ling tor
them, and YOU will receive quite as mucn
milk and butter in return, as was derived
from the former mode OF treating twenty,
Sweet potatoes, carrots, pumpkins, ana
ground oats, are unquestionably among the


best articles of food for mich cattle; they
occasion the milk to assume hne flavor ana


colour as well as an Increase OF quantity.

full articles.headline:
THE FARMER.

HUSBANDRY.
full articles.article:
It seems not generally apprehended OF II
apprehended, not acted upon, that husoaha-
~ or farming, like the mechanic arts, IN or
der to be most profitable to those engaged
in il. lshould be divided and subdivided INTO
its distinct and separate branches. Inc
blacksmith to his anvil, the cobler to his last,
the carpenter to his adze, and SO on OF the
other branches of mechanical labors; no one
thinks of CARRYING on all these at one and the
same time.-But the farmer appears not TO
appreciate the advantage OF conflning MS Ia
hors to any one branch OF husbandry, the
converting of effort and attention to one
Doint; and yet this is, in fact, as important
in husbandry as in mechanism. AND u Is
owing TO this mistaken policy, no doubt IN
great measure, that the art of husbandry
has advanced SO slowly, and the profit SO
small in comparison to the labor. A mo-
ment's reflection will show this natural re-
suit. By having tNe attention divided a
mong all the various branches. no one be-
comes particularly skilled in either, and
hence no branch becomes particularly pro
ftable. By keeping few cows for dairyln
a few swine, few sheep, fattenlng is"
beeves raising little grain, little max, &c.
the attention and resources OF a common tar
mer are SO divided, that the whole yield but
discouraging result; whereas, by conflnlng
his attention to either of these, or taking on
ly such as bear the nearest affinity and as.
sist one or the other he may hope to be-
come an adept in that particular branch,
and realize a corresponding profit. And IN
selecting the particular branch he will pur-
sue. the husbandman should not rashly a.
dopt that which chance speculation may
at the moment cry up as the most protita-
Bile; but should, in the first place, consider
for what his farm is more particularly a.
dapted, and what his resources will enable
him to have most perfectly at command; an1
then steadily and perseveringly pursue ~ I


AS the cobler to his last, so let the ! his [
man stick to his cows. the grazies. thro,


beeves, the wool grower to his Rtion. and


all the uha and dozYns Of spest either in
there is little apprehension complain that
the end will have cause abor, or is not
he gets no profits in hsperity
sharer in the general

yiunar Ohserv atiOns.


HENRY HEALD,
full articles.article:
Has opened his ACADEMY, at his residence, in
French street, two doors below Third street,
where will be taught the different branches of
practical Mathematics; the method of taking and
working Lunar Dissertations with the uses and
adjustment of all the instruments used in the
branches taught.


Should sufficient encouragement be given to
afford lt,a small photographic and Printing Press
will be attached to the Institution, by which the
pupils may be exercised III composition; Perspec-
tive and other drawings, things, essential to the
practical Scholar.


Pupils from distance will be accommodated
with Boarding at Two Dollars per week.


Sent pl 1896 ST..

full articles.headline: LAZY ron.
full articles.article:
britten By DR.. ----. Pretend # ----, 0
his serrant, during q fit # ne eo,t.
Would you view man that's slow,
Come and sec our fontmam Joe:--
Mu j unlike the bounding doe,
Or the arrow from the bow,
Is the pace Of foetman joe
Crabs, that hobble to and fro,
In their motions copy Joe;
Snails, contcmptuous as they go,
Look behind and sneer at doc;
An acre any man might NOV,
While across it crawleth lazy joe
Trip on light fantastic toe,
Who loves tripping may for Joe
Measured steps and solemn voc,
Better suit with steady joe
Danube, Severn, Trent and Po,
Backward TO their source shall flow,
Ere despatch be made by Joe;
Letters to the Penny Pc,


Send not by our footman Joe;
Would you Jobs full patience know,
Ring the bell and wait for joe
Whether it be King or no.
IT'S all the same to lazy Joe.
Is your cash and credit low
Let your debts be paid by Joe
Legal process none can know,
If your lawyer moves like Joe.
Death, at length, our common foe,
AIuct t,,t, ma tha heels Df I0a
And stone shall tell ssbelow
Scarcely changed still slcepeth Joe
Loud shall the final trumpet blow,
And the last conner shall be Joe.

YOUNG LADIES'
BOARDING SCHOOL,
full articles.article:
At this Seminary, which is now open for the
reception of pupils, all the useful, and most of
the ornamental branches Of education are taught
with unreusted diligence; and every attention
paid to the health, manners, and morals of the
young ladies'


The terms of board and tuition, per quarter
$50, paid in advance. Extra charges for music,
and other ornamental branches.

DIR. Wilson, Rev. DIR. Janeway, Mr.. William
Janvier, merchant, James Thompson, Esq Pro
fessor Of Languages, University of Pa. Phila.
Wilmington, Nov. I'd, 1926. c.

full articles.headline: CULTIVATION OF BARLEY,
full articles.article:
rs hrGcttsed 6y the best Furmers IN EnS-


land. =.


Barley delights in sandy loan. Itror
erallv succeeds wheat, the land beingii ~
en- IN as soon after Christmast as r ,nro,s. H
NIT the plough lts ploughed ar, ;a, i !. !.
ed in March. In April the opfaf,ara..rtIe
gain repeated; the outstanding harrow ,rr and
taking care to render with y.n IND rs lev
roller, the entire surface stha rronnd i on
el as possible. Sometip'e seed sown above:
" ploughed once. and i ;s hroken bv three
but more frequents standmu they NAV not
ploughings, notwweek TO perform them in.
have more thasht. appears an injudicious
This, at hrsn,lonab bnes m being 50 qnick up-
pract'ee, her, neither the root weeds have
on eacRither, nor the seed weeds to vesct
tlmeBut this being frequent practice Of
aye of the best farmers, we may be assur-
ID that two ploughings and harrowngs are
lot wantonv thrown away.-lhe Norfolk
srmers are in general masters OF the art Of
barley. They seem fully aware
if the tenderness of this plant ~ is infant
state, and of its roofing being un Bile TO
make the proper progress IN a compact y
proper soil; they therefore strive by every
means in their power, to render the SOL as
fine as ashes, and fit forthc reception Of the
seed. The proper TING for sowing the seed
is from the middle OF April to the midele Of
MAY; but the time depends in some measure
upon the season; the true period sJnst be-
fore the oak iut& on Mat &ailo72 ahflear-
Qnce, which il does At the time the buds are
breaking, previous to the expansion OF the
leaves. Three bushels are usually allowed
to an acre, and sown broadcast; il is then
ploughed under with shallow furrow, an
admirable practice in soils light enough to
produce good barley, provided the seed is
not buried too deep. If tire season howev-
er is wet, and the soil cold and heavy, the
seed should be cast upon the surface, aud
then narrowed and rolled. as is the practice
in other districts.

full articles.headline:
.esaaylvania Pater.
Tfo" 9KCHARDS.
full articles.article:
come proyerbial, that "where


1t has. hard has stood, a young one will
and olde" This has been SO frequently
not Hed, that many of our good agricul-
Rests have subscribed to the opinion,
ithout taking the trouble to examine into
It, and have accordingly neglected very
important source of profit and convenience.
1t is fact much to be regretted that the
cultivation of fruit trees in this country was
much more attended to half a century since,
than at the present time--consequently
with our increased population, fruit has be
come scarce, and belief almost positively
exists, that fruit trees will not thrive OH old
land: This question needs serious consider
alton, that eur yeomanry may no longer
take hypothesis for fact, when but one ex
pertinent would dispel the Illusion.


We, however, admit the fact, that trees
planted on new land thrive uncommonly
we'll, and many of them grow to great
size, while those planted on land that has
been much cultivated and worn have been
tardy in their growth, and as yet are but
awarfs in comparison with the former Now
we will endeavor to explain the reason of
this admission which we trust will at the
same time throw some light on the art of
cultiyating fruit trees


/. Trees, planted fifty or one hundred
years since, were generally set on new land
highly enriched by the decayed vegetable
productions, which have been accommodating
perhaps from time immemorial. The rich
ness OF the soil would, without doubt, enable
the trees to grow rapidly, and very abund-
antly explain the reason of their monstrous
growth.


Q. An orchard set on the ruins of an old
one, has not this vegetable manure to lend
the aid that its predecessor had; consequent
ly, it is slow In its growth; small and unpro-
ductive when grown, becomes mossy, dwin-
dies and dies or is neglected as unworthy
the husbandman's attention; and the cater
pillar destroys what the axe has spared
Our climate and soil are every way calcu-
lated for the production OF fruit III its per-
fection and abundance, when only assisted
by the fostering hand OF art-and it is unrea-
sonable to anticipate harvest without pre-
vious cultivation, the early days of our
country the earth needed only the seed to be
gown to produce a rich harvest for its DO.
som was enriched and softrncd by natural
manure. The case is now different--it has
been skinned by grandfather, father and son
twice or thrice repeated until its face is sad
ly wasted.-Who is there among US, thai
would suppose tree would grow when un.
assisted by art, Or land thus impoverished
The farmer who thinks Of raising a gooe
crop of corn knows well the necessity O
sottening, manuring, and frequently stirrin,
the earth-on this depends his success Sup
pose he should say, with regard to his coin
as he does in fact OF his trees--my grea
grand father planted without hoeing or ma
nuring, and was sure of the increase, and
will do lkewise-would he not be STYLED
madman or fool? Let the husbandman be
stow the same care on am orchard, that h
does on field of corn, and he will be bles
with the same abundant harvest.


To him who doubts the possibility
making good orchard on old land thes
few simple rules are enjoned, and we dout
not, upon experiment, his happy convel
sion to truth that will increase his wealtl


1. Be sure that the roots of the trees /
below the soil. If the soil is shallow, bring
from another place, and throw it round th
tree, in sufficient circumference for the roo
TO grow in.


II. Prune the superhuous limbs an
branches and keep the bark smooth an
clean from moss.


Ill. Suffer no grass to grow within te
feet of the tree, and twice in the wear, sprin
and fall, loosen the earth in circumference,
and mix into it full wheelbarrow load
Iich manure.


The author is happy to state that fe
years experiment upon this plan on tn
ground Of an old orchard, has convinced hi
ehAt the principle oDpogcd to this rule

full articles.headline: GoOsFBF,RRIEs.
full articles.article:
Gooseberrics require dead and rich loam
the ground must be well maliured and kept
free from weeds; and be careful to plant
none but those that are of good kind. lie
best mode of propagating them, is by cut
tngs or layers. Earlv in the spring, spade
carefully around the roots, turn overthe soil,
and pull out all grass that may grow near
them. Prune them by cutting out every
worn out, decaved, or irregular branch--et
none be permitted to grow across each 9th
er; but let all be pruned 10 some regular or
der--cut out all the super-abundant, lateral
shoots of the last summer, close to the
ground, or old wood, otly retaining Eere ard
there good one, to supply the place Of cas-
ual worn out bearers. Never permit the
extremities Of the branches to stand nearer
than six or eight inches 10 each other. The
best form for we'll trained gooseberry or
currant bush, is that of vine glass.


Gooae5erry It'ine is made il the same
manner as currant wine, except that one
